   Assessment and Plan
   89 yo F with PMH of DM2, diastolic CHF, aflutter, gout and presented
   with continued fatigue and tachycardia noted by PT at rehab.
   .
   # RHYTHM: Atrial fibrillation, reccurent. She is s/p failed
   cardioversion (x2), w/ hx of reversion to SR w/ volume resuscitation.
   Pt. did not repsond to diltiazem, possibly [**3-16**] volume depletion.
   Clearly not responding to volume resuscitation this time around.  The
   cause of afib is unclear, bu likely [**3-16**] structural disease w/ [**Name Prefix (Prefixes) **]
   [**Last Name (Prefixes) 3038**].  No pulm or infectious causes apparent. Pt. may have become
   tachy [**3-16**] volume depletion (GIB or poor PO intake).  in addition, pt.
   is volume overloaded, likely contributing. Possibly also contributed to
   by hypocalcemia, but unsure if the lab results from ED are valid. Per
   previous OMR d/c summary, she was poor candidate for  anticoagulation
   with coumadin and patient and daughter were in agreement of not
   anticoagulating.  Per discussion w/ daughter, comfort is the goal of
   care at this point.
   -monitor on tele
   - continue asa
   - D/C IVF as pt. vol overloaded
   - Will attempt another IV diltiazem, in unsuccessful, will consider
   amiodarone drip to help convert patient
   - Repeat ECG in AM.
   - Will discuss w/ family and PCP further goals of therapy regarding
   antiarrhythmic as OP.
   - Holding PO dilitiazem.
   .
   # PUPM.  Diastolic CHF, most recent echo w/ LVEF > 65%, symmetric LVH
   and elevated PAP.  On lasix 80mg QD at rehab.  Currently volume
   overloaded on exam, but will hold diuresis given recent hx of
   hypotension are 5L IVF resuscitation in ED. Pt. likely requiring this
   given loss of atrial kick and impaired relaxation.
   - Monitor I/Os.
   - Holding lasix until pt. converted to sinus rhythm and given recent
   hypotension, will likely restart once converts.
   .
   # CORONARIES.  CAD documented on previous D/C summaries.  No
   documentation of coronary anatomy in OMR.  Pt. w/o anginal sx currently
   but had SOB as anginal equivalent.  No lipid panel in OMR.  Will
   discuss w/ PCP the utility of assessing further, given goals of care.
   - Continue ASA
   - Discuss lipid panel in AM w/ PCP.
   .
   # Hypotension in ED.  Now resolved. Likely from rapid rate and
   hypovolemia (unclear source of this).
   -monitor
   -hold dilt for now, will consider best antiarrhythmic in this patient
   for rate control vs. rhythm contorol
   -holding lasix for now
   .
   # Abnormal CXR.  Opacities b/l.  No clinical sings of PNA, no fever,
   WBC count, productive cough.  Likely resolving infiltrates from prior
   PNA.
   - No indicatin for ABx.
   - Will monitor fever curve, WBCs and sx.
   .
   # Electrolyte abnormalities.  Unclear source. Pt. on lasix, but CBC
   erroneous from ED labs.  Repeat chemistries pending.
   - will reassess and replete lytes prn.
   .
   # Diabetes type 2 with complications: hold oral agents and use insulin
   SS for now. Check finger sticks.
   .
   # Gout: continue allopurinol and colchicine
   .
   # Osteoporosis: continue calcium and vitamin D
   .
   # FEN: heart healthy, diabetic diet. hold IVF for now.
   # ACCESS: PIVs (femoral pulled)
   # PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with subcutaneous heparin
   -Bowel regimen
   #CODE: DNR/DNI, No pressors.
   #DISPO: CCU for now.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:

Summary:
The patient is an 89-year-old female with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2, diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF), atrial fibrillation, gout, and presented with continued fatigue and tachycardia. She was initially given diltiazem 10mg IV, but it did not have an effect on her heart rate and she remained in atrial fibrillation. She had a blood pressure reading of over 100mmHg and was started on amiodarone bolus followed by a drip, which successfully converted her to sinus rhythm at midnight. The patient was able to move around and use the commode without complaints afterward.

Her allergies include sulfa (sulfonamides) and an unknown allergy. Her last dose of antibiotics was not mentioned. The patient is currently on amiodarone infusion at a rate of 0.5 mg/min and has received diltiazem in the past.

The review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below. Her vital signs include a temperature of 38C (100.4F), current temperature of 35.8C (96.5F), heart rate ranging from 72 to 147 beats per minute, blood pressure ranging from 116/57 to 137/77 mmHg, respiratory rate ranging from 23 to 27 inspirations per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on nasal cannula.

Hemodynamic monitoring shows

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 89-year-old female with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2, diastolic congestive heart failure, atrial fibrillation, gout, and previous myocardial infarction. She presented with continued fatigue and tachycardia. She was given diltiazem without effect on heart rate, and her atrial fibrillation persisted. The patient also exhibited signs of congestive heart failure, so no more fluids were given while on the floor. She was started on amiodarone bolus followed by drip, which converted her to sinus rhythm at midnight. The patient became asymptomatic, able to move around and use the commode without complaints.

The patient's allergies include sulfa (sulfonamides), with an unknown allergy to another medication. Her last dose of antibiotics was not specified. She is currently on amiodarone infusion and other ICU medications. The patient refused subcutaneous heparin.

Review of Systems is unchanged from admission except for the noted below.

- Tcurrent: 35.8°C (96.5°F)
- HR: 72 bpm (72-147 bpm)
- BP: 116/57 mmHg (71-137/77 mmHg)

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 89-year-old female with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2, diastolic congestive heart failure, atrial flutter, gout. She presented with fatigue and tachycardia, which was found to be due to atrial fibrillation. The patient underwent cardioversion twice but remained in sinus rhythm. She was treated with amiodarone and her symptoms improved. She has been on diuretics for diastolic congestive heart failure and hospice care is being set up. The patient will be discharged home on amiodarone and will go back to rehab.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's recent episode of atrial fibrillation could lead to complications such as stroke or heart failure.
2. Diastolic congestive heart failure: The patient has a history of diastolic congestive heart failure, which can cause symptoms like fatigue and shortness of breath. It may worsen if not properly managed.
3. Hypotension: The patient experienced hypotension in the emergency department, likely due to volume depletion. This could be a concern during her discharge and if diuretics are restarted.
4. Chronic kidney disease: The patient's elevated creatinine level indicates potential chronic kidney disease. This may require further evaluation and management.
5. Electrolyte abnormalities: The patient has electrolyte imbalances, including hypocalcemia and hyperkalemia

TEXT:
TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   89 yo F with PMH of DM2, diastolic CHF, aflutter, gout and presented
   fatigue and tachycardia found to be in a. fib which broke with
   Amiodarone, now with reoccurrence of atrial fib.

   Assessment and Plan
   89 yo F with PMH of DM2, diastolic CHF, aflutter, gout and presented
   with continued fatigue and tachycardia noted by PT at rehab found to be
   in a.fib.
   # RHYTHM: Patient had converted from a.fib on admission when given
   Amiodarone, however she went back into afib overnight.  Continues to go
   in and out of a.fib.  Was given an Amiodarone bolus and started on an
   infusion overnight.
   -  Continue Amiodarone infusion (already received 1 mg/kg for 6 hours,
   now getting 0.5 mg/kg for 18 hours); once finished will restarted
   Amiodarone 200 mg daily
   -  In the past there was discussion about anticoagulation and it was
   decided that she is not a good candidate given her age and risk for
   bleeding.  No anticoagulation.
   -  Will start Metoprolol 25 mg tid for rate control with Amiodarone.
   -  Will monitor for bradycardia and QT interval prolongation on
   Amiodarone.
   .
   # PUMP.  Diastolic CHF, most recent echo w/ LVEF > 65%, symmetric LVH
   and elevated PAP.  On lasix 80mg QD at rehab.  Patient put out over 3 L
   yesterday to the 80 mg of lasix.
   - Monitor I/Os.
   - Will decrease her lasix to 40 mg daily, given her large output to 80
   mg.
   - Morphine prn for SOB
   # CORONARIES.  CAD documented on previous D/C summaries.  No
   documentation of coronary anatomy in OMR.  Pt. w/o anginal sx currently
   but had SOB as anginal equivalent.
   - Continue ASA
   # Diabetes type 2 with complications: hold oral agents and use insulin
   SS for now. Check finger sticks.
   # Gout: continue allopurinol and colchicine
   # Osteoporosis: continue calcium and vitamin D
   # FEN: heart healthy, diabetic diet. hold IVF for now.
   # ACCESS: PIVs
   # PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with subcutaneous heparin
   -Bowel regimen
   #CODE: DNR/DNI, No pressors.   Patient will be transitioning to hospice
   in the near future.
   #DISPO: patient can be called out to the floor and can likely go back
   to rehab tomorrow once she is finished with the Amiodarone loading.

Summary:
The patient is an 89-year-old female with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2, diastolic congestive heart failure, atrial flutter, gout, and presented with fatigue and tachycardia. She was found to be in atrial fibrillation (a.fib) which broke with Amiodarone, but now has reoccurrence of atrial fib. The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.7 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 89 beats per minute, blood pressure ranging from 143/59 to 176/98 mmHg, respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient's heart rhythm is currently in sinus rhythm. 

The patient received a 200 mg dose of Amiodarone, followed by a 150 mg IV bolus and an infusion of 1 mg/kg for 6 hours, then 0.5 mg/kg for another 18 hours. She also received 5 mg IV Metoprolol to control her rate overnight. The patient denies chest pain, shortness of breath, dizziness, palpitations, or other complaints. 

The patient's allergies include sulfa (sulfonamides) and unknown allergies. The last dose of antibiotics was given on [**2110-1-18**]. The patient is currently receiving infusions of Amiodarone and Metoprolol, as well as other medications

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an elderly female with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type 2, diastolic congestive heart failure, atrial fibrillation, gout, and chronic venous stasis changes in the lower extremities. The patient presented with continued fatigue and tachycardia. 

The patient was found to be in atrial fibrillation and converted back to normal sinus rhythm upon admission when given amiodarone. However, she went back into atrial fibrillation overnight and received an amiodarone bolus and started on an infusion. The plan is to continue the amiodarone infusion and restart amiodarone 200 mg daily after finishing the infusion. 

The patient also has diastolic congestive heart failure with a most recent echocardiogram showing left ventricular ejection fraction greater than 65%, symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy, and elevated pulmonary artery pressures. She was on Lasix 80mg QD at rehab but was put out over 3 liters yesterday despite the Lasix. 

The patient's coronary arteries show documented coronary artery disease, and she has been prescribed aspirin. Her diabetes type 2 with complications is being managed by holding oral agents and using insulin sliding scale. 

The patient has gout and osteoporosis, for which she is continuing allopurinol and colchicine, as well as calcium and vitamin D supplementation. Her diet is heart-healthy and
